There is insufficient evidence to demonstrate a link between smoking and lung cancer.

problem: A(n) ________ variable affects the variables of interest and may give the false impression of a causal relationship.

choices.choice: control
confound
dependent
independent
subject

problem: Sandra strongly believes that attending daycare is detrimental to children’s development so she decides to write her psychology term paper on this topic. She does a literature search and finds several sources supporting her opinion, but she finds that the majority of research indicates that children attending daycare experience healthy development. She ultimately writes a paper using the sources that find negative associations with daycare attendance. This is an example of ________.

choices.choice: type I error
confirmation bias
hawthorne effect
observer bias
demand characteristics

problem: A within-subjects experiment must involve a minimum of ________ participant group(s), and a between-subjects experiment must involve a minimum of _______ participant group(s).

choices.choice: two; one
one; two
two; three
three; two
one; three

problem: The ________ group does not get the experimental treatment, and is needed to examine the potential effect of that treatment.

choices.choice: alternate
control
dependent
non-bias
independent

problem: A(n) ________ is a description of how the researchers will measure the variables of interest.

choices.choice: experimental plan
hypothesis
operational definition
theory
placebo

problem: Sukhbir is interested in studying the way writing skills relate to gender. She believes that men are better at writing than women are. She administers an essay exam to a group of subjects, and grades them herself. Because of her expectation that men will do better on this exam than women, her grading may not be fair. What form of bias is likely to affect her behavior?

choices.choice: availability bias
framing effect bias
participant bias
the placebo effect
confirmation bias

problem: Carter and Madison are five years old and they both say that are sick. Their father gives them a “special medicine” (a sugary gummy bear) and immediately after taking it, the kids report feeling better. Their improvement is most likely due to:

choices.choice: the active medicinal effects of the gummy bear
the placebo effect
practice effects
between-group variability
attrition

problem: The ________ are selected and measured by the experimenter to examine the effect of experimenters manipulation.

choices.choice: confounding variable(s)
dependent variable(s)
independent variable(s)
experimental variable(s)
subject variable(s)

problem: Devine et al. are interested in assessing whether active versus passive play causes a preference for sweet or salty foods in toddlers. They assign groups of children to either an active play, passive play, or no play group and record their food choices when presented with a variety of sweet and salty foods. In this study, ________ is the independent variable and ________ is the control group.

choices.choice: active play; passive play
type of play; no play
food choice; no play
no play; type of play
sweet food; salty food

problem: Harrison et al. are conducting a study assessing the ability of depressed versus non-depressed participants to remember negative emotions in a short story about a family whose car breaks down. They plan to ask participants to read the story and then make a list of the emotions expressed in the story. In this example, negative emotions are the

choices.choice: independent variable.
dependent variable.
operational definition.
significant variable.
confounding variables.

problem: Which of the following is false regarding random sampling and random group assignment?

choices.choice: it improves the researcher’s ability to generalize their findings
it may weaken any effect that the independent variable has on the participants
it ensures that each participant has a fair opportunity to be in any of the conditions
it increases the likelihood that the groups reflect the variability in the population
it helps protect against favoritism for some participants

problem: What is one task that a peer reviewer is not encouraged to do?

choices.choice: conducting his or her own research in the same subject area
take the ideas from articles they review and use them as if they are their own
looking for potential flaws in the way a study was conducted
suggesting additional research or statistical analyses
verifying that the research meets ethical standards

problem: Peer reviewers are essential to the scientific process because they

choices.choice: push through work that is consistent with previous research
help ensure quality control in reporting scientific findings.
they control the only way that science is shared: through scientific articles
approve research done by top researchers, which is the primary way we advance science
allow for a researcher’s friends to give their “stamp of approval” on their work

problem: Suppose Dr. Boyd finds a very interesting result about the relationship between brain stimulation and recovery from stroke. But, when she tries to find the same result again in three subsequent studies, she is unable to do so. It is fair to say that her initial finding was:

choices.choice: lacking a sampling bias
not reliable
not actually statistically significant
suffering from a confirmation bias
more valid than her subsequent studies

problem: Some studies that cannot ethically be conducted as experiments with typical human participants are

choices.choice: actually possible to test with participants from prison populations.
possible to test with animal studies.
actually ethical in the sense that scientific knowledge is more important that participant welfare.
not possible to test with empirical methods.
possible to test with college students.

problem: Which of the following is the most commonly used subjects in animal research?

choices.choice: cats
rats
rhesus monkeys
pigeons
pigs

problem: _______ leans on the fact that the data have already been collected, and _______ allows you to collect large amounts of data with relative ease.

choices.choice: Naturalistic observation; experiments
Archival research; surveys
Correlational research; experiments
Archival research; experiments
Correlational research; surveys

problem: American researchers studying the effects of physical attractiveness on compliance wish to expand the cross-cultural generalizability of their findings to a Lebanese population. They travel to Lebanon and recruit local residents, whom the American researchers rate as attractive or unattractive, to act as experimental confederates. However, they are unable to replicate their research findings in the Lebanese sample. Which of the following is the most compelling reason for why this might be so?

choices.choice: Inter-rater reliability cannot be assessed with the Lebanese sample.
There may be differences in standards of attractiveness between the different cultures.
Language barriers prevent research studies from being used in other countries.
Americans are significantly less attractive than those who are Lebanese.
Researchers outside the United States are held to different standards than Americans.

problem: Longitudinal research is important to psychology because it allows us to track how someone changes over time. However, collecting longitudinal data is made more difficult by the fact that some people may not complete the study for known or unknown reasons, a problem known as:

choices.choice: selective participation.
attrition.
the cohort effect.
limited generalization.
participant weakness.

problem: Magali is interested in studying happiness. She defines happiness as “how a person rates their happiness on a scale of 1-5, where “1” is the least happy and “5” is the most happy. When she compares her work to already published studies, she finds that it agrees with some work and disagrees with other work. Given what you’ve read here, which of the following is least likely to be true?

choices.choice: She may be using a different operational definition than other researchers.
Her work is accurate but every study that conflicts with hers is inaccurate.
Her happiness results may be true in her sample, but not in other samples.
She may be comparing her study to studies that are different in kind, making the comparison unreasonable.
Her operationalization of happiness may not properly capture happiness.

problem: An upper-level psychology class is conducting an experiment on racial prejudice that involves having participants rate the likeability of faces in a set of photos. However, they tell participants that the study is about the effects of aging on likeability. When participants are finished, they are thanked for their time and leave the experiment. Debriefing is always an important practice, and is especially important here because this study involved _______.

choices.choice: upper-level psychology students
deception
a contentious topic
likeability
reviewing photographs

problem: ________ can be used to assess ________.

choices.choice: Reliability; validity
Statistical analyses; reliability
Dependent variables; independent variables
Validity; reliability
Correlation; causality

problem: The ________ variable measures the effects of the _______ variable.

choices.choice: control; dependent
dependent; independent
independent; dependent
dependent; confound
confound; dependent

problem: The only study design that allows you to examine whether there is a cause-and-effect relationship between two variables is a(n) ________.

choices.choice: correlational design
experiment
archival analysis
survey
meta-analysis

problem: Which of the following is false regarding animal research?

choices.choice: A different ethics board evaluates animal research compared to human research
Animal research is done whenever is it the most financially beneficial to the researcher
The goal of researchers is to phase out the use of animals as soon as possible
When alternative methods to animal research are developed, they should be favored
Researchers must always work to promote the welfare of animals and to minimize any pain or discomfort wherever possible

problem: A major advantage of case studies is the

choices.choice: improved generalizability.
detailed information.
a larger sample size.
no experimenter bias.
the ease of data collection.

problem: The commonly accepted statistical threshold for data not occurring by chance is p = _______
